Hi--

I need to extend the thermophysical properties of several gases in 
CANTERA to lower temperatures.  For example, hydrogen (H2) currently 
seems to have a lower limit of 200 K, I need to extend it down to 
cryogenic temperatures (~20 K).

I am getting new polynomial fits to the JANAF data using the "old" 7-
term polynomial form for my various gases.  This will satisfy my 
thermodynamic data source requirements.

For transport properties (viscosity & thermal conductivity), I do 
not have a complete listing of the various calculational forms used 
in CANTERA.  If I did, I would be able to fit low-temperature 
literature data and extract the best "diam" and "well_depth" 
coefficients.  

As an alternative, I was going to use MATLAB to do a least-squares 
fit to literature data, and determine the best diam and well_depth 
coefficients without needing to know the exact form of the viscosity 
& thermal conductivity calculations.  However, as I was trying to 
find a starting point for this procedure, I was manually varying 
CANTERA's diam and well_depth coefficients, and found that I cannot 
get a viscosity for temperatures below 60K, and I cannot get a 
thermal conductivity below 100 K!  This is regardless of how small I 
make diam, and regardless of how large I make well_depth.

The error message I get for H2 viscosity below 60 K is (diam = 0.1 
and well_depth = 2, vs the default of diam = 2.92 and well_depth = 
38.):

===begin===

??? <no Cantera error>

Error in ==> c:\program files\cantera15
\toolbox\cantera\cantera\ctmethods.dll
Error in ==> c:\program files\cantera15
\toolbox\cantera\cantera\@Transport\private\trans_get.m
On line 5  ==>   v = ctmethods(50, n, job);

Error in ==> c:\program files\cantera15
\toolbox\cantera\cantera\@Transport\viscosity.m
On line 2  ==> v = trans_get(a.id, 1);


====end====

The error message I get for thermal conductivity below 100 K is:

===begin===

??? <no Cantera error>

Error in ==> c:\program files\cantera15
\toolbox\cantera\cantera\ctmethods.dll
Error in ==> c:\program files\cantera15
\toolbox\cantera\cantera\@Transport\private\trans_get.m
On line 5  ==>   v = ctmethods(50, n, job);

Error in ==> c:\program files\cantera15
\toolbox\cantera\cantera\@Transport\thermalConductivity.m
On line 3  ==> v = trans_get(a.id, 2);

====end====

My questions are:

1.  Re: my errors below 60 or 100 K, is there a built-in lower limit 
in CANTERA's transport properties that has to be removed?  Or some 
other way I can force it to go down to ~20 K?

2.  Are CANTERA's calculational methods for viscosity & thermal 
conductivity (both pure components & mixtures) detailed in a 
reference? (Is it "Marerro and Mason, J. Phys. Chem. Ref. Data, vol. 
1, p. 3 (1972)" [in TransportFactory.cpp] for pure components; and 
is it "Dixon-Lewis (1968) and Kee, Coltrin, and Glarborg (2002)" [in 
tut6.m] for multicomponent or mixture-averaged models?)  I've 
started looking at CANTERA's source code . . . found the collision 
integrals . . . and I hope that a summary might be available, to 
insure that I get it right.

TIA,

--Keith
